title: Rostock Max V2 Layer fan shroud large 50mm

description.text:
The original layer fan of the Rostock Max V2 is a little small in order to really cool down PLA layers. I wanted something better and ordered from 3DWare.ch 3 50mm fans with a 15x20mm large opening. I used a part of the original shroud and added geometry in order to mount the blower fan.
The Rambo board can drive the fans without problems.
I've currently installed one only - and if I use 100% flow, my extruder temperature decreases already from 225°C to 215°C (with the stock hot end) --> I might use a different hotend in future - probably the E3D V6.

This is the stock layer fan shroud from SeeMeCNC: http://repables.com/r/621/
This is the fan: http://szrunda.en.alibaba.com/product/60299874260-50158483/DC_Blower_Cooling_Fan_50_15mm.html

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Printed in ABS for higher temperature stability.
No support was used, printing orientation shown on image.

I used the original fan shroud front side and added a different fan adapter for my Fans. Model: RUNDA ELECTRICS Co. LTD. DC12V / 0.23A
ordered from 3DWare.ch.

3D Application used:

  • Autodesk Fusion 360
  • Meshmixer for reducing original shroud STL model complexity in order for Fusion to be able convert it to a component

comments.text: Yes, printed as shown in the image. There was no support required at all.

Of course parallel. The Rambo board has no problems to drive all 3.
I'm using only one fan at usually 60% speed. It was so far enough to cool my prints.

title: Full Graphic Controller Enclosure Mount for Robo 3D

description.text:
I couldn't find a Full Graphic Controller Enclosure mount for Robo 3D that I like, so I created my own version from scratch. This one will mount on like the Robo 3D spool holder on to the right side. All the parts will fit together snug without need of glue or screws. You can print the stop button in different color if you like. My full graphic controller came with knob so I didn't create one. This is made for the one I order off ebay shipped from China (red pcb).

This is a tight fit on the Robo 3D. Make sure the ribbon cables don't get snagged or pinched.

title: Cake container rotating nozzle head extruder V2 spool filament case protecter

description.text: By adding a rotatable ball V2,the idea was to keep my filament dry by using a round clear cake container,thus stopping the filament from becoming brittle, the filament can easily move from side to side when the print becomes larger or higher,like a round plug in a sink,it should stop moisture from getting in,,i put a couple of siIicon pillows inside the cake container, I added a male cap connector on the end of the ball, plus a female cap moisture stop plug,the plug works fine on the ball and nozzle while the printer is working. Moisture & dust free flexible filament all the time .Happy 3dPrinting.: )

Just a quick remix of my older Technician's wallet design - as I'll be flying to the USA soon, and needed some different gadgets.
Many of you said that the radio tracker wasn't as useful as I felt it might be, so also I re purposed that space.
If flying with this, I recommend you leave the wallet ninja in your check-in luggage.

Also added, room for a ring up to size X 1/2

This unit now has room for:

7 X credit/debit cards (9 without wallet ninja and business card)
1 X business card
1 X wallet Ninja
4 X micro SD cards (+1 in the adaptor)
1 X Standards SD card (Or SD to micro adaptor)
1 X micro USB OTG adaptor
1 X 20mm paperclip
1 X floss pick
1 X ring up to X 1/2 (wedding or other)
1 X USB powered dimmable lamp
1 X USB Micro SD card reader
1 X USB Nano Wifi Adaptor
1 X Sandisk Nano USB stick (64/128/256GB types)
1 X Verbatim Nano Ultra thin USB stick (32/64 GB types)

I'm using BluTac as a precaution to secure some of the smaller items.
Some of you in the USA may not have heard of this - despite it being a NASA invention by 3M. It's very common in Australia in most supermarkets and stationary stores.

Optionally - you could remove the ring, USB lamp, and card reader and keep $12 AUD in $2 coins.
In practice I have found that 3 X Australian $2 coins will fit inside a stored ring of size X or above.

Printed in ABS with a nice hot bed of around 90c

title: Simple Hexagonal Packing Within A Circle

description.text: This is an extremely simplified version of Circle Packing algorithm for filling the area of a circle with other circles. It by no means is anywhere near as complicated or accurate as real-world circle packing algorithms and I'm sure could be improved upon as my OpenScad skills are fairly new and i'm sure the math could be cleaned/simplified. It creates a hexagonal grid of points at which we draw a circle on. Based completely on the work @ Red Blog Games and ported to OpenSCAD, specifically the Movement Range section.

title: iPhone 6 plus bicycle mount w/ quick release

description.text:
I took the idea from DPC and redesigned the latching system. It's a turn and lock system now. Also I redesigned the top and bottom to allow it to fit with the rubber Apple case.
the only file I used from DPC was the crown mount that takes the hose clamp. I re-created everything else with DPC's design

Everything should be able to print without rafts or supports, but I would recommend a brim of about 12mm

Instead of the hose clamp, I used two big pan ties.

There is some assembly required with the crown latch. two stage epoxy works the best

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa geeetech i3 X

Resolution:

.02

Infill:

10%

Notes:

PLA Temps: 200 degrees first layer, 215 degrees all other layers
Bed Temps: 70 degrees first layer. 45 degrees all layers

3 layers top and bottom and sides

123D Design

It's in the latest revision, and I will test ride the clamp and make revisions as needed.

author: simonhead

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:47842 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=47842

Using the following options: Font = write/orbitron.dxf
Nut_Size = 12
Tool_Length = 10
message = StudioBlue
Tool_Height = 5

This is a smaller version of the filament drive made by Jag. I made this from scratch in Sketchup, but based most of it around his design, because the larger 3mm version worked well. This, and the 1.75 settings were all I needed to immediately get the thinner plastic working. Requires no extra support, they are built into the model.

If you make this, you may want to make the base a little thicker, because the screws on the bottom hit the plastic past the nut before tightening onto the platform. Other than that, it has worked great.

author: Mach3tte

description.text:
My printer is a brandless Prusa i3-styled printer that I purchased off eBay.

The extruder that is came with was useless. It was constantly jamming, under extruding and 'clicking'. One of the first mods I did was replace the junk extruder with an e3d v6 extruder and a bowden tube. None of the other e3d brackets on thingiverse would work on my printer - not even the prusa i3 ones, so I had to design my own. Here it is.

Printer:

eBay

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

description.text:
When I was growing up, my dad always kept old 35mm film canisters around the house as convenient storage for small quantities of nuts and bolts, nails, and the like. I realized that since few people use film anymore, that the film capsule is slowly going extinct.

So, in the interest of maintaining a well-organized, versatile toolkit, I made my own. As best as possible, all dimensions are true to the original standard-issue grey-top black-bottom 35mm film canister.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Folgertech 2020 Prusia i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

The body can be any rigid material; the cap, however, needs to be printed out of a flexible material. I used Alchement black flexible TPU from Amazon, but most Ninjaflex-like filaments will probably work. Flexible filament was used in the design because that was the way the old-style 35mm film capsules were made. Let me know in the comments how other materials work.

The other childhood memory of these film capsules was making Alka-Seltzer-powered "pop rockets" I haven't tested how well these will hold pressure yet, but presumably they will work nearly as well as the real thing. For those who aren't familiar, the procedure is as follows:

  1. Collect some paper, water, and Alka-seltzer tablets.

  2. Roll paper around the film capsule to make the body of the rocket. The capsule should have the cap pointing down at the bottom of the tube, and the cap should be easily removable. This capsule is your rocket engine.

  3. Fashion a paper nose cone to put on the other end

  4. Go outside, somewhere you don't mind making a mess.

  5. Hold the rocket upside-down, and pour in enough water to fill about the bottom quarter of the capsule. You can experiment with the amount of water used, as it will change how the rocket flies.

  6. Drop in the Alka-Seltzer, and quickly cap the capsule. Quickly set the rocket down, back away, and prepare for launch!

Note: I take no responsibility for any messes or explosions that may result. Use with care. Adult supervision recommended.

title: Fan Comb
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This hair comb is made to hold long hair in 'updo' styles that were popular several decades ago and are coming back (or so I'm told). This design was made to recreate a friend's favorite comb which is no longer sold anywhere.

I created the model by taking measurements from the existing comb and recreating the design in Fusion 360. The angles were approximate and took some fiddling to get just right. The only real change is that the teeth on the STL are flatter on the underside so they stick to the bed more easily, where the original had rounded edges.

My hair isn't long enough to use it... but instruction manual can be found online for anybody interested:
http://www.xovain.com/hair/retro-hairstyles-using-side-combs
http://nymag.com/thecut/2015/01/how-to-wear-a-hair-comb-like-keira-knightley.html

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Modified Folger Tech Prusa 2020 i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Keeping your bed level is the most important part for this print to turn out right. If you are too far away the teeth will lose adhesion and separate from the bed mid print. Keep your bed hot, somewhere around 60 C.

Printing them one at a time is the most reliable. I had some success printing two at once, but the teeth are more likely to come up before they're finished.

description.text:
After spilling the roll of dog poo bags countless times because the lid falls off and breaking commercially available equivalents by accidentally stepping on them, I broke down and designed my own rugged durable Poo Bag Dispenser. It accepts the standard roll of bags found in pet stores.

I designed it from the ground up using SketchUp. Contact me if you want a copy of the skp file. If you print the stl file as is, it results in a very rugged unit that has survived several drops and being stepped on several times. The two slits allow the body to flex to accept the lid yet keep it on tightly. After you attach the lid to the body for the first time, twist it back and forth to loosen it up. I tried making the loop out of plastic, but it just isn't strong enough to put up with carrying it dangling from the retractable leash we use to walk our dog. So you'll need to fashion the top loop out of a piece of shirt hanger wire or something similar and attach it to the bottom using a couple of small diameter machine screws and nuts. Place them with the head inside poking out so that the screw ends don't interfere with the bags. Feel free to enlarge the hole (using a drill) if you're using a larger diameter screw. Let me know if you have any questions.

title: Dancing Cat Back Scratcher, Puppet and Toy
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
“Here comes Dancing Cat…bum, bum, bum…He wants to scratch your back…bum, bum, bum!”

Includes Dancing Cat in three different poses, each in a separate .stl file.

The first pose in file “DancingCatBackScratcher.stl” makes the best back scratcher. If you only print one design, print this one, it’s probably the best one. The rear legs are crouched with the front legs in good position for blissful scratching, with the head down to more easily slide around under your clothing.

The second pose, “DancingCatBackScratcherAlt.stl”, makes the best puppet. It has the back legs straight, the front legs at a 45 degree angle and the head up. This version is good for scratching outside your clothing, playing with your cat, and as a child’s toy or cat’s toy. It prints with less support.

In the last pose, “DancingCatLeaping.stl” the legs are outstretched in a leap. This one makes the best cat toy. This design prints best right side up but doesn’t make a very good back scratcher and won’t hang, it is more of a puppet. It uses support mainly for the tail.

Stores by hanging onto ledges and large containers. The extra long tail serves as a handle. Up to nine lives per file.

Can now print a version with a lid. Still can print with no supports, scad file can be edited for either version.

About

The excellent Aus3D IR proximity sensor board (http://aus3d.com.au, http://wiki.aus3d.com.au/IR_Probe_1.4) is designed to fit standard 30mm E3D extruder cooling fans. Printers that don't have E3D fan mounting points need a mounting bracket.

Here is a bracket designed to replace the induction sensor on the x-carriage mounting point of a MaxMicron printer. The OpenSCAD file is given as well so the design can be adapted to other printer mounting points.

The adapter is in two parts, a shell and a retaining bar, that are positioned in a single STL to print.

The shell has a space to allow for the reverse side pins under the LEDs and receiver. The side has a simple slot for the plug. If a taller wall size is used then the slot becomes a hole, with modest bridging that shouldn't require any supports.

The retaining bar has a small edge inset to prevent pressue being applied to the board IC, and it is printed inset side up and needs to be turned over to fit the shell and hold the board snugly.

The bar can be fixed with any M3 nuts/bolts. On the MaxMicron the mounting flange is a wide enough that it interferes with the heads or nuts of a fixing bolt, so a countersunk head bolt can be heat seated, gently, using a soldering iron and just enough heat and pressure to get the head to lie flush with the back of the shell.

Then it is just a matter of mounting the sensor on the x-carriage flange.

MaxMicron Dual Extruder Autoleveling

No

0.2mm layer, 0.4mm nozzle, 0.5mm tracks

Infill:

Notes:

PLA

description.text:
We designed this for the Icom ID-5100, so the defaults fit that radio, but in general you should be able to customize for almost any ham radio of roughly the same shape. You'll need a good ruler or calipers to measure the radio dimensions and in particular the distance on center between the screw holes on the radio. So far when printed with ABS this is surprisingly strong (3mm walls probably help)

I highly recommend these screws for most radios: https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B01F5COC42

Please customize for whatever radios you have! See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1656282 for a customization of this with pictures.

EDIT: Unfortunately there is a feature we're using that requires a newer version of openscad than what customizer works -- you'll have to download and change and run in the latest customizer to take full advantage of the customizability :-(

• Got a Mom?

I told my daughter that I would be able to give this to my Mom (Grandma) as well and she doubled in excitement making sure I would tell Grandma that she helped make it too! bmsweb alerted me that his Mom is a Mum, and Mum's count too! comments.text:
Question - do you have the stock HTD 3mm belt, or do you have something else? If you both have the same machine, how do you have different belts? That would require different pulleys at the least, to go with the different teeth spacing on the carriage. I'm a bit confused...
= = = = =
Ok, lacking a response, I printed one and measured it. While my unit doesn't make parts good enough to use, I can confirm that this part does use a 3mm tooth pitch, and it has a fairly wide gap for the belt. That's fine, as if it proves to be too big, it's a simple thing to shim it and fill the gap. See the "Made" tab for photos of my (sloppy) print of it.

description.text:
This is a remix of the life size Iron Man Mark III Helmet by MIPRESIDENTE. It just isn't going to fit on my print bed, so I'm in the process of cutting it into bite-sized chunks. The first step of that was to separate some of the combined parts.

These are the same parts as in the original file. They've just been separated from one another into individual files. I've tried to put these in the best print orientation, but you'll want to double check this for your own printer. Print the earpiece twice.

I'm also cutting it up into smaller chunks because, well, its still too big for my printer. If there's interest, I'll post those files as well once I'm done with them.

Thanks to MIPRESIDENTE for the original model.

description.text:
This is a modular toolbox design to hold some of the commonly used tools in 3D printing. I initially created the modular design to accommodate the limitations of printing the parts, but this also allows you to change the design of the insert without re-printing the filament consuming base part. The back of the base is cut out in a trapezoid shape and requires that your printer is able to bridge 60mm. I use the redesigned Configurable 40mm Fan Duct by AndrewBCN (Thing 540716) which allows printing bridges very nicely.

title: Externally Accessable Y axis belt tensioner for Taz 3-5 Printers

description.text:
The Taz 3d printer needs an easier way to adjust the Y axis belt tension, as well as provision to add a Y maximum endstop. This project addresses both those issues.

Please note: This project requires drilling a single hole in your Taz Y idler endplate. Please only proceed if you are comfortable drilling holes in printers.

The tensioner works fine, I haven't tested the endstop allignment yet, so please be aware that portion may change.

Build thread is here:
https://forum.lulzbot.com/viewtopic.php?f=16&t=4773&p=28402

Update 1 - The belt mount holes are for m3 bolts, not M5. Be sure and use the correct Heat Set Inserts.

Update 2: new tensioner version and belt block uploaded. this version is a bit stronger and easier to add the lower heat set inserts into. The new tension block allows you to structurally tie the front and rear tower together since you are adjusting the tension at the front anyways.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.5mm Nozzle

Infill:

85% or better

Notes:

Printed in ABS, the bed portions may get warm depending on your setup so PLA is not reccommended.

Instructions:

You will need 1 M4 bolt (12-14mm), 1 M4 washer and 1 m4 Nylock nut. You will also need a m4 bolt sized drillbit, 4 1/4" spacers, 4 bolts to fit said spacers. I think I used 6-32 x 1/4 x 1" nylon spacers and 6-32 cap bolts. But really anything similar will work. You may also want to get longer bolts and add a washer and a nut to the end to secure the idler assembly in the event the m4 bolt fails. You will also need 2 m2 heat set inserts and and 8 short M3 inserts for the replacement Y max endstop target

To install, bolt the drill guide to the idler plate with it and the attached hardware removed from your Taz. Drill the hole and clean any aluminum swarf. Install 2 m2 heat set inserts in the Y maximum endstop plate, and the m3 heat set inserts into the Y max endstop target.

Next thread the 6-32 bolts through the idler plate (note the position of the plate should have the offset side to the right when viewed from the front) and through the Y maximum endstop adaptor plate, then tighten the spacers. Now install the M4 nut into the tensioner, then the stock Taz M8 bolt idler hardware set (2 m8 washers, 2 608zz bearings, 1 M8 bolt and nut) into the idler body and place on the posts as shown in the pictures. Now you can reinstall this on your Taz.

To start, adjust the M4 bolt so you have a 3mm or so gap between the back of the idler assembly and the front of the Y maximum endstop plate where the posts attach. now re-attach the belt usinng the stock lulzbot plates and hardware and get hand tight. Now turn the bolt to adjust tension as needed.

Enjoy!

More pictures and better instructions to follow. Also why dind't someone tell me I had Y and Z swapped?

comments.text: Is there any particular reason the nylon spacers need to be threaded or can I use unthreaded spacers?
comments.author: joshz

comments.text: 2 reasons. The spacers need to thread onto the bolt that holds them in place on the front frame plate, and they need to be threaded to accept the "oh crap, my 4mm bolt broke or came loose because i unscrewed it too far and now my tensioner is flying forward" stop bolts and washers. You could use an unthreaded one and then tap it out or just force it with a larger bolt, it doesn't need to be particularily smooth there, The tensioner just needs to be able to move in and out on the spacers as guide pins. I suppose you could also use one long bolt with a nut on one end.
comments.author: joshz

comments.text: Yeah, that was my plan... I was going to use a longer bolt with a nut and washer on the end and a smooth spacer (since that's what I have handy, and there's no place to buy threaded spacers that I've found locally). I feel more comfortable with that anyway, since it wouldn't be relying on plastic threads to hold any tension. Granted, you've got 4 to keep the tension, so it's unlikely they'd all have an issue, but I never like relying on plastic threading for anything involving force if I don't have to. Also don't have to worry about stripping anything if I tighten it down too much.
comments.author: piercet

comments.text: I was looking at them more as "fuse" parts. Normally they wouldn't have tension, but if they did end up under tension i'd rather they break before the front plate bent or the belt broke, but I want them to be able to take a little bit of tension in an emergancy. I can see someone unscrewing the M4 bolt all the way. A future variant might include deliberatly marring the threads on the end of that bolt to prevent it from coming undone.
comments.author: joshz

comments.text: Is that a micrometer for adjusting your z-axis? Thats awsome!
comments.author: cody3D

comments.text: Thanks! Yes it is indeed, good eye! I find it works great. The biggest problem with manual leveling using the old spring and screw target is that the spring exerts a bit of pressure on the bolt, and repeated heat cool cycles tend to make it migrate up and away from the bed, which is why so many people have frustration with that type of setup. by using a micrometer barrel, it just stays where you put it essentially forever.
comments.author: cody3D

comments.text: Great, Thanks.

It's good to know there is interest though, I'll bump it up the priority list.

Solidworks, Meshmixer, Simplify3D

I then used Meshmixer to slice the Fort Wood Plinth STL into sections, such that each can fit to my printers bed allowing you to scale as needed.

remixed_from.author: RichRap
remixed_from.title: Filament joiner for multicoloured printed 3D objects

description.text:
The Filament Fuser Block enables you to securely fuse two ends of 3D printing filament together in roughly 10 seconds. With this tool you can recycle leftover filament, extend the length of your filament spools for long prints, and add color changes to your prints!

The printed parts enable you to safely hold the heated block under a hinged guard, and clamp everything to the side of a table. It works on 2.85mm and 1.75mm filament in any printing material. The Fuser Block is controlled by plugging the (3) two-pinned connectors into your existing 3D printer controller, so you can precisely control the temperature!

These 3D printing models are shared here for free, but to complete the assembly you'll need the associated hardware kit from the EngineerDog Store here: https://engineerdog.com/store/filament-fuser/

Complete assembly and use instructions available on 3D Printing.com here: http://3dprinting.com/how-to/fuse-filament-home/... See image attached for recommended print settings

Video Demo: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bnTNdcKsNT0

Update: Now included is a printable jaw cover that fits on standard 6" slip joint pliers. Using grooved pliers to squeeze a freshly made warm joint with as it cools helps compact it and further strengthens the bond.

UPDATE 1: This device is intended to be controlled by your existing 3d printer controller. This is super easy for a reprap printer, but difficult for some commercial devices. My recommended solution for a stand alone controller is to get the cheap complete reprap ramps kit and just use it for this purpose. (After you get it setup you wont even need to connect it to your computer!)
Available here: http://amzn.to/2dODHgg

UPDATE 2: New part "Clamp Face V2" is intended to replace the original clamp face. The new one doesnt require a nut to do the job!

remixed_from.title: Parametric Involute  Bevel and Spur Gears

description.text:
This is a quick mod of the High Resolution Herringbone gears for Greg's Wade Reloaded extruder. Specifically the small Herringbone gear that attaches to your stepper motor on your extruder. I've been having some problems on my Homemade/ Homebuilt Lulzbot Mini with what i thought was heat creep, but which may have been a clogged nozzle. At the same time this little gear keeps coming loose and could be contributing to my printing problems. Therefore i have made a small mod for it to have two set screws placed 90 degrees from each other. This in theory should help a lot. I'm surprised it was not designed this way to begin with. Enjoy.

I have yet to print it and test it, but i will soon. I will try to upload a photo when i do. Until then i will publish this early like most of my designs and thingiverse uploads.

Created to store my API brand water test kits for use with my aquariums, aquaponics garden setup and koi tank !

Displays 5 test kit colour charts & holds 5 test tubes (with or without cap on base) & has space for up to 10 test kit bottles.

I am not affiliated with API !

Printer:

Yasin 200 Dual Extruder

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I printed in Yasin Grey PLA (1.75mm).
Print the Tray Handle oriented vertically, with the star shape on the print bed.
I did not need raft.

Slide the Tray Handle into the bottom of the Tray Base until flush. It is intended as an interference fit, and slid together well on my print, and is retained well (but can be easily popped back out). You may need to trim if your print tolerances are larger than mine (!)

Having had all the test kit bits in a plastic box under the bench and fed up with where to put the test tubes during a test, I designed this holder to house all the API kits I have.
Whilst it is good for storage, it is also designed to be useful during a test to hold the test tubes and have the colour chart right there when needed.
Designed this in Solidworks.
If you want the source file to create a remix, drop me a line

description.text:
This is a 3D printed bowtie! It's designed to be segmented. This way it can be joined by string and flex, plus you can print it in different colors.
You can check out how I assembled it here: https://youtu.be/WKoOM_OGp5c

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20-30%

Notes:

Most pieces don't need support if printed with the flat side down. I do however recommend supports for the innermost segment of the bow part.

Glue the center sections and thread each lobe to it one at a time using fishing line or stretchy jewelry string.
Finally, Glue the clip if you want to wear it as a bowtie or don't if you want to glue it as something else.
Check out the video for more details!

Yes

0.2

I wanted a wire manager for my iPod Nano 3G that would: (1) allow the wire to be coiled up for storage; (2) be attached to the iPod; (3) allow full use of the Nano, including access to all controls and ports, without disassembly -- this precluded wrapping the cord around the face of the iPod; (4) allow partial or full uncoiling with lockdown of the cord.
I didn't care if it bulked up the iPod somewhat. In the end, it's still comfortable in a shirt pocket, either fully coiled or partly uncoiled for listening. However, if the reason you stopped smoking was that the cigarette pack was too uncomfortable in your pocket, you might not like this device.

The photos show a PLA print made on a Prusa Mendel Reprap. This is a 3rd-gen object not only because its' for a 3rd-geniPod Nano, but also because it is the 3rd iteration of the design; the first one was just for practice; the second was printed and in fact, the large image of the assembly (the one that looks like a flying saucer) depicts the 2nd-gen model. Going to the 3rd-gen, which the other files and photos show, I deepened the spool to hold more wire, lengthened the pins from 1mm to 2 mm, and created additional slots (8 instead of the 2nd-gen four) for greater convenience of wrapping and holding the wire down. The earbud cords press-fit into the slots. The slots are in several widths, and so should accommodate several brands of earbuds, but you can always file them out for greater width. The stl for the spool came out 10x actual size; I don't know why it came out that way. The parts were designed in Sketchup. Since Sketchup cannot handle sub-millimeter dimensions (how brain-dead is that?), the holder is at the meter scale. I did the spool at the cm scale. In both cases, I used the skp-to-dxf plugin to produce the stls. In both cases. I specified 1mm scale, so go figger. Neither stl could be printed at the start. This is almost certainly due to subtle flaws in the .skp files. You can see them at large magnification if you look hard for them. However, both stls could be fixed using cloud.netfabb.com and the fixed stls are the ones shown here. These .stl's also have the right dimensions. Xendi (http://www.thingiverse.com/Xendi) printed the pieces. He used slic3r to generate the Gcode. He also helped produce the .stl's. Some post-printing work needs to be done to assemble the device:

  • The pins on the spool should match the holes in the holder, but might be off a bit, depending on the calibration of your printer; so you might have to use a file to shave down the pins or enlarge the holes.

  • The slots, when printed, had wisps of PLA in them. They take some patience to clean out. Useful tools: mini files, sandpaper, single-edged razor blade, even a fingernail file.

  • To do the assembly, I heat-bonded the two pieces. After I got a good fit to the pins, I held a piece of aluminum foil in a forceps over a pin where it protruded through the holder, then melted the pin down with a soldering iron on the foil (to keep from fouling the iron). I did this for the four pins. Superglue should also work for PLA and acetone for ABS.
    • Go to wiki.hackmanhattan.com if you want to read the long and rather boring log of the trials and tribulations along the way. Getting there was half the fun for me but probably not for you.

description.text:
PLEASE READ CAREFULLY THE BOTTOM OF THIS DESCRIPTION FIRST ! This is an attempt to create a 3D sculpture out of the famous "Screaming Hand" design from Jim Phillips, a famous designer for Santa Cruz skateboards.
Note that it's an "attempt" which means it's not accurate and far from perfect... Modeled with Meshmixer and Sculptris. For more information please visit http://www.reppersdelight.spacymen.com/index.php/post/2013/10/14/Screaming-Hand-3D-sculpture SKATE or DIE !!! Edited : I also uploaded the left hand for those who want to print a model that is closer to the original design Edited : I have intentionally deleted the files for download because after reading things here and there I'm just afraid I might have done a copyright infringement. Sorry folks !
I know I should have think about it before but honestly as I am not a lawyer it didn't jump to my mind at all.
And as I can't afford a lawyer (I don't even have a job...) I prefer to not take any risk.
I'm just going to contact Jim Phillips first and might reload the files only if he is OK with that.
I hope you understand... ===========================================================
EDITED after receiving an answer both from Jim Phillips and NHS.
And here is the answer : "Ambrose, your 3-D print of the Screaming Hand is amazing, however, according to NHS inc, it is not OK to post the 3D printed sculpture as this is an infringement to make, or allow others to make, any reproductions of the now Globally Trademarked Screaming Hand design." - Jim Phillips AT ALL THE PEOPLE THAT DOWNLOADED IT :
Please don't post that thing again here or anywhere else.
If I find out that it has been uploaded back I will ask Thingiverse to make sure to suppress it ASAP ! AT JIM and NHS / SANTA CRUZ :
Thanks for your replies and sorry for all the trouble. ===========================================================
This thing is the :
  • most-seen
  • most wanted (say it with a "I like")
  • most liked (thank you people, thank you!)
  • most downloaded (in the time it was available - no more than 24h)
    • thing that I published so far. FREE 3D PRINTING OR DIE!

I haven't 3D printed it yet and I bet someone will probably do it before me...  
Print it either in ABS or PLA with support.  
The sculpture should be able to stand on its base.  
Happy printing !

description.text:
Parametric USB Organizer with screw holes (on the back) to mount it on a wall.

There are many models for USB holders/organizers in Thingiverse but all I cound find were in one row so I made a model with OpenSCAD and decided to share it here. This model is suitable for wall mounting.

This model is a customizable model, you can use Thingiverse Customizer to customize.
Body:

  • number of rows
  • number of columns
  • spacing between the holes
  • corner radius

Screw holes (on the back)

  • diameter of the screw head
  • diameter of the screw shank/threat
  • height of the screw head
  • tolerance of the screw head hole.

Connector

  • size of the connector (the defaults are for USB A)
  • tolerance of the connector hole which you can tweak so the holes aren't too tight.
    I have used 0.3mm which gives a snug fit.
    Please note - if your printer is not calibrated you should use something like 0.5.
    The tolerance can also be filament brand/type dependent due to shrinkage. So test it with a small piece before you print a large one.

I needed some mindless vermin and settled on the giant flea. So, based on this clipart I whipped up a simple flatmini model with Tinkercad. You can edit it.

Nothing fancy, but I thought there's at least a chance someone else will want to print one or a dozen =)

The print's look pretty awful, I know. My Makerbot must have had a bad day ... The hind legs are a bit to tiny and might break, but other than that the models hold up. There's a lot of residue on that's probably possible to clean up, but I thought it added to the slimy, distrusting presence of giant bloodsucking fleas.

If you're familiar with Flatminis, you'll probably notice I haven't used the standard 25mm base. Instead, I made an oblong base, 25mm in one direction but significantly shorter in the other. I think these will fit better on my Openforge tiles, where several squares are partially covered by walls. The normal 25mm one is included in among the .stl files.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/fqzBp5Gxtyl

A model of the Toy Soldiers Unite Member mascot. V1 is with teeth outside the head, v2 with teeth inside the head.   
I tried to add minor angels so there would be no undercuts on the model.

FIRST 2 VERSIONS: Load the model and print; no assembly necessary. :) TSU_Soldier_Figure_v9 [3 files]
This version should be the final one for the soldier!
The head is made in three parts: the small puck is a Key that will fit snugly into the head. You can leave the neck as is so he can look around!
I recommend bonding the legs to the torso and the hat (and pin) to the head- it's a snug fit and shuldn't come off, but a permanent bond may be better! ROTATE THE MODELS!
  • print legs base down
  • print torso with flat surface and large hole on bottom
  • print head UPSIDE DOWN: the puck in the center should be in contact the the platform.

comments.text: Had my friend print it on his Prusa, came out pretty good. The waist belt overhang had some trouble, but clean otherwise.

comments.text: A quick tip, when assembling the Z-AXIS, the brass nuts need to be perfectly perpendicular to the threaded rod, otherwise they will jam and prevent the smooth movement of the Z-AXIS.  So start by gently tightening the supports around one of the nuts, while repeatedly rotating the Z-AXIS (by hand is ok) so that you can make sure the threaded screw rod moves freely, then repeat for the other nut.

comments.author: eremit

comments.text:
In the original Hubsan, there are at the arms, facing upward, at the most outer point. Wich looks good.
Outermost point is not possible with SumSum, because it has no material there (nice Idea, and rare between all the other frame designs).
Conventional way is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:229994. It would be good to have the mounts on the front of the frontarms (if the cam catches some light, you can notice when it starts to go on and off, signaling batterie low). And on the rear of the rear arms symmetrically.
And an interesting version a bit like in a car here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1572867. Could be cool when flying in the dark, for some cams, this should even provide enough light for flying. (Thrilling Idea: Explore your dark living room with the pale blue light in FPV Flight :-)
The right spot would be where the body ends and the arms begin. If it would not result in a big support structure amount, I'd suggest to place them on the downside, also acting as a kind of skid, protecting the motor bottoms with especially the wires. In that case, the open part of the holding claw should not point to the bottom, but to the sides.
The led is 5mm long, and has a diameter of 2.8 mm (it's not quite a circle) . There is a sort of a 1mm bottom ring, wich has a diameter of 3,8 mm.
( There are two led's to the front and two to the back. It looks different in the picture, suggesting 6 or 8 leds. That is because there are another 2 blue led's on the flight controller)

description.text:
This is a storage container sized to fit in a 3,5" HDD tray. It is meant for storing extra screws, cables, plugs, tools, and what not, inside the computer so you always have it on hand when you need it, and never have to look for it in the cabinet in the far end of the basement or whereever you used to store the spareparts or extras that came with your hardware.

This is version 1.0 beta, which means i am printing it at this very moment, also meaning i am not sure if it fits or works at this moment, but feel free to leave feedback, and i will adress it when i get the time for it.
UPDATE V1.1 resized mounting holes in the box. it turns out that the holes was twice as big as supposed to, due to a calculation error.

It has the same dimentions as a 3.5" HDD with the holes placed in the same places, and the holes should be in a size so you can screw the M3 screws which is normally used for installing HDDs in the holes. The holes is made without threads, but since its plastic it should be straight forward screwing them in.

title: My temperature or temperature/humidity sensor
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My needs :
1/ I wanted to make temperature and temperature/humidity sensors based on oregon protocol to have a full compatibility with my RFXcom.
2/ I wanted it to have a low consuption.
3/ I wanted to choose either temperature only or temperature and humidity sensor.
4/ I wanted to use simple and cheap elements : less than 5€ each sensor.
5/ I wanted to put all this in a box i could fix on a wall, inside or outside.
This is all done.

About electronic part :

  • attyni85 (low consuption),
  • DS18B20 (temperature sensor), DHT22 (temperature and humidity sensor),
  • simple chineese low cost 433MHz emetter,
  • 3 AAA batteries cheap support (i did not have a printer when i started this project..., one can make its own),
  • put a 10uF capacitor between +5v and ground,
  • emetter data pin on attyni85 pin 2,
  • for a DS18B20 : VDD on attyni85 pin 3 and DQ on attyni85 pin 4, and 4.7k resistor between VDD and DQ,
  • for a DHT22 : VDD on attyni85 pin 3 and DATA on attyni85 pin 4 (simply the same as DS18B20), and a 10k resistor between VDD and DATA.
  • don't forget to put an antenna on the emetter (16.5cm wire is a good choice).

About firmware part :

  • I use arduino IDE because it is so simple... My attyni85 are programmed with internal 8MHz clock. I let you seach on your favorite web search engine how to do this.
  • If one wants to use DS18B20, uncomment "#define SENSOR_TYPE_DS18B20" and comment "#define SENSOR_TYPE_DHT22" and vice versa...
  • Each sensor must have its own "MY_ID", change the line "#define MY_ID 0x06" for each new sensor. Comments give exemples (used in my house).
  • NB_CYCLES_DODO is used to tune the time between two mesuse. 20 for about 2'30", and proportionality is your friend... The more you send datas, the less your battery goes on. I wanted one mesure each 5 minutes, but i have big heavy walls, so i send the double to "ensure" i'll get one each 5 minutes.
  • VCC_BATTERY_LIMIT, in mV, tells you when it is time to change batteries. Be aware you have between two weeks and a mounth when it happens (sensor in yellow on domoticz) until it reaches 3.3v and starts sending mad datas (-127°C for example).

Improvements :

  • Since two years, I only changed the battery once on DS18B20. For DHT22, i still have to tune the code, it's about 3 mounth the battery set.
  • Newly, i made the boxes, so it was time to share. I use 3.5mmx16mm INOX (remember the box is designed to be used inside or outside) screw. But all is upside down inside the box, under the batteries, it really can be improved.

I was asked to share it with a technology teacher who thought he could use this in his classroom, so i share with the classroom 3D, unless it is not all about 3D...

title: Vertical axis turbine in a tunnel Wind
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The aim of this project is to charge a mobile phone using Wind Energy, this avoiding the need os the mains.

A very high percentage of the main´s power supply is obtained from fossil fuels. For this reason the use of Wind Energy is preferable as it is a clean form of energy, wich would reduce our dependence on gossil fuels, the conflicts created in other countries and the impact on the enviroment. In addition it would help save money and provide energy in places that have no access to the mains.
To achieve this, a test bench will be developed to compare the performance of the different wind-driven generaters to scale. The test bench will measure the following parameters.

-The turning speed of the different prototypes.
-The wind speed inside the wind tunnel.
-The mechanical torque produced by the diferent prototypes.

title: Beach umbrella holder for your bike

description.text:
Have you ever wanted to go out for a ride with your bike, but it’s so hot and sunny you‘re going to melt like an ice cream in august?
We have the solution for you!

With these easy printable pieces, you can use a standard beach umbrella and ride in a continuous shade that is always above you. And if you have a waterproof beach umbrella, you can also ride when it rains. And there is more!, you can use to transport your beach umbrella
It is adjustable to different angles in order to fit different bikes. You’ll only need ten M4x12mm screws and nuts. Adjust angle and mount center screw first because later it won’t fit. There are two different supports, with and without hole (upper and lower supports respectively).

I used 0,2mm layer, 30% infill (for extra toughness) and no supports.
Enjoy summer with your bike and without sunburns!! And if you like it, share!

title: 1:24 Scale Residential Model Objects
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These items are designed for use in a 1:24 scale (1/2-inch = 1-foot) architectural model.
These objects are custom modeled directly from the objects in my personal home, which I designed and built myself.  However, they are common household appliances and construction components that can be used in just about any design.
More architectural objects will follow.  Download the PDF for brief instructions on how to build your own 1:24 scale home model, and to see what other objects I plan to design for my model home.
The actual photos of my home are for model relation purposes. My 3D model of my home is accurate to within 1/64" in most areas.
2-7-2012:  Uploaded a few more progress pictures of the project.  I took photos of my TV screen, pellet stove window, and the "bricks" in my engraved concrete entryway, and printed them out on photo paper (to scale), cut them out, and glued them in the appropriate places.  Looks great!  :)

Download the PDF file for very basic instructions on how to build your own 3D home model.
Download the residential model files that you wish to use.
Print them.
Use your imagination, your patience, and any other skills you have.  
Refer to the Internet for basic construction techniques and geometry calculations, if you must.  
Last resort... ask me and I'll help.  :)
Have fun... that's the entire point.
DESCRIPTIONS OF FILES:
1)  Shower base:  This is a fairly common 60" shower base, but I added 1 wall of my shower to fit my custom Master Bath arrangement.  Cut it off in 3D or after printing, if you don't need it.  This prints great!
2)  Toilet:  A pretty standard toilet.  I printed 3 of them using MULTIPLY, and everything worked great until it got to the tank.  The base of this toilet is pretty small, and the tank hangs off the back of the base.  I printed it with a raft and 10mm/sec speed, but the toilets still toppled over when they got to the tanks.  Experiment... it's healthy.
3)  Tub/shower unit:  A standard 60" tub/shower unit with grab bar and soap dish.  It prints great!
4)  Pellet stove:  Probably not a popular thing, but I included it anyhow.  It prints great, and is a popular supplimentary heating device in my neck of the woods.  :)
5)  Oven/microwave:  I designed these 2 items together, since they are commonly used together.  Pretty basic print, and turns out well.
6)  Refrigerator:  This is a pretty standard side-by-side refrigerator/freezer unit with a recessed water/ice receptacle and seperate handles that you can glue on later or throw away with the raft.  For faux stainless steel (as with the other appliances, use aluminum HVAC duct tape and carefully cut around the handles and the ice/water receptacle).
7)  Sound system:  A pretty basic model of my sound equipment.  A 400-disc CD changer at bottom, then a 600-watt digital THX-certified surround-sound/stereo receiver, then a satellite receiver, then a Blu-ray player.  Don't plug it in after you print it.  It won't save you $6,000 and you may end up in the hospital.  :)  
8) TV:  A common 42" flat-screen TV, with a mount printed seperately.  There are grooves on the back of the TV for mount alignment, and an arrow that should point up in relation to the TV, to make the TV angle down just a bit.  (The angled facet on the face of the TV is the bottom.)
More files to come, as I have time.  I can also take requests, and will do my best to fulfill.  I have libraries of various building components that I've designed on CAD, and can print just about anything I need to.  I also have several CD-ROMs of Kohler, Anderson, Pella, and many other construction-related files, which I'm sure I can convert to STL for your use.  Just let me know what you need.  But PLEASE give me a long lead time.  I'm a busy, busy, busy bee.  ;)

This is a cool adjustable SD holder and it’s called SUP!
Although it is aimed to computers displays, as it is adjustable, it fits other places up to 16mm thick and can store up to 7 SD cards. For example I use it with my display but also on my Prusa i3.

Nut and bolt are designed separately for two reasons. Firstly, so you can use different printing settings. Secondly, because this part can be tricky if you don’t have your printer well-tuned, so if you have problems printing the screw, you can use a standard M8 screw and nut instead.

I printed all parts at once with different settings thanks to Simplify 3D and ZYYX+ 3D printer, but you can combine colors as you wish. Head is printed with 0.2mm layer and the rest with 0.1mm layer. With my ZYYX+ 3D printer, I reduced extrusion multiplier to 0.9 for the nut and bolt and they work perfectly out of the plate.

The design is intended to be combined with a custom wallpaper. I uploaded an example but I’m not a graphic designer, as you can see ;), so I challenge you to design some wallpapers and post them here or on the project’s webpage www.makitpro.com, LET YOUR CREATIVITY OUT!

Remember to upload pictures of your prints and…
…be careful with SUP, it is always watching you! ;)

Happy printing!,
Makitpro

description.text:
The gear in my rotary tool press long since shattered. I was able to design somewhat of a replacement in OpenScad with the shattered remains of the original!

It works well - however the design of the press seems to use the cover to hold the gear in. The original gear was deeper, and maybe didn't rely on the cover as much for support.

I taped the cover of the press with duct tape just to be sure.

If you wanted to further design this, you might have luck flipping it upside down when printing, printing it on a raft, and extending the gear down, and shortening the sprue where the spring attaches. You may also want to shrink the inside of the gear hole's diameter by 1mm for a snugger fit. The gear works very well as is for me, I think these things might just make it better.

Disclaimer: 3D Printed parts may not be as strong as original cast parts. The gear holds the drill in the up position. It's a drill, never have your hand under the bit, always wear eye protection. if this part were to fail, the drill would fall to the down position. Just like when the original failed, though! The gear is also under constant torsion load from the spring.

Edit: Uploaded v2, it fits better. You'll have to hot-knife off the support structure in the STL, tho, or generate your own via the SCAD.

title: ST:TNG Warp Core
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I really liked the style of the Warp Core Table Lamp done by ThePlanetMike, but at the time, there was very little information about how the lighting was done. Also, the light pattern was not the same as seen in the show. So, I thought I would try doing my own lighting and came up with this. A lot of the pieces are a complete redesign from the original. The chamber and matter injector have some modifications, but are based off the original pieces.

Here is a video of the final product.
https://youtu.be/5eExqwx-PhE

I used a custom adapter to an Arduino Nano to control the lights. The PCB can be ordered from OSH Park (https://oshpark.com/projects/OjKfgvHc). You will need some skill in surface mount soldering to assemble the board.

I am a Software Engineer, not an English Major or manual writer. I will be the first to admit that my writing is not the best. I have tried to do the best I can to describe how to assemble things. Successful assembly will rely on the users mechanical and electronic skills. This is not a novice level project.

NOTE: The No Derivative restriction only applies to automated processes or being used as part of a combination of objects. Derivatives are allowed as long as the derivative is a stand-alone object.

NOTE 2: The SMD resistors are 0805 type.

comments.text: Thanks for the comment.  Glad you asked that question because it made me go back and check.  I discovered I have a mistake in my parts list.  Instead of the 2N7001, it should be 2N7002.  The mosfet is rated at 350ma.  It should be able to handle around 15 LEDs, depending on the current draw.  I did modify the center display of one that I built using a similar strip of LEDs (don't remember the density). I believe I used the same piece and just hot glued the strip down. comments.text: One other thing I meant to mention about the current. If you look at the schematics, you will see that there are two sets of rings running off a mosfet, which is 16 LEDs. I have a lamp that has been running continuously since I posted the project and there has been no failure of the mosfet. So I think they will handle the strips just fine.  You might consider adding a second set of mosfet for the rings as I don't know how well it would handle 24 LEDs.

comments.text: One thing to keep in mind is the 350ma is for continuous.  Because the LEDs are pulsed, you can exceed that amount.  Since you are going to breadboard it, you can use another MOSFET that has a higher current rating.

description.text: This is a multi-section, 3D printed feeder for rabbits and other small animals. There is a lower bowl section and upper hopper sections. There is also and option lid. You can use just one hopper or maybe two or three if you have more space and want to have more feed in the storage section. I used clear PET filament as it is useful to see the level of feed left in the hopper sections and it is food safe. Although rabbits are supposed to eat mainly hay this feed is useful for occasions when an animal has to be left for two of three days. It just about prints without supports although you may find the internal slope section bows slightly with some plastics, but it'll still function OK. I've added an optional bevelled lip for the bowl section to reduce the spillage of the feed as the animals eat.

Remix of the Core-XY C-Bot and D-Bot with much thanks to all their and their communities work

305mm x 305mm x 457mm print
$650 approximate cost (But who knows at this point given all of the experimentation I have done)

Please note that this thing is a continuous work in progress and not all files have been uploaded yet.

UPDATE FEB 2018
  • Now 362 x 322 x 457 mm print volume
  • Step file of build attached.
  • Includes several imported designs from various sources, listed in my remixes (Thank you to all!!!)

• Larger than the original to allow for 1.5 cubic ft of print volume.
  • Fully enclosed with all motors located outside of the heated chamber area
  • Modified X axis end caps to allow for cantilevered V-Bearings, freeing the sides of the Y rails for case mounting
Cantilever Y axis bearings with aluminium plate Build Plate Cantilever Z Axis Dual Extruder (E3D V6) Auto Capacitance Based Z Leveling UPDATES FEB 2018

I have been constantly evolving this design.

  • Re made the aluminium end plates and shifted the 3d printed mount aft by about 1cm to allow for a larger print volume and for the titan extruder to fit in front of the carriage
  • Whole new z axis setup. I still stand by the cantilever design posted earlier, but in the quest for a more reliable and predictable machine I have switched to a fully constrained approach. Bearings are now rolling on the front and aft vertical V-Rails. They are compressed against the rails via bolts. I believe this was inspired / printed from 1sPiRe's work. It took some care in insuring the vertical rails were very close to parallel. At the same time, I added a belt to link the two z axis motors. This was not necessary for operation but made maitenance easier as I didn't have to worry about one side getting out of sync. The belt tensioner was borrowed from JonnayLin's J bot design. Additionally, I fianlly put a cover over the bottom area (I used dollar store foam core)

At first I perfectly centered my two Z screws front to back but found I was having a few issues while keeping a perfectly flat bed front to back. This led to two adjustments. I shifted the screws aft by 4 cm to allow gravity to preload the bed in one direction. Additionally, I replaced my springy z axis motor couplings with spider couplings. I can't tell you which was the solution but the combo did the trick and as you can see in the photo, I get a perfect first layer now.

Again, with inspiration from 1sPiRe's build I re constructed my X carriage. I based the concept on 1sPiRe's work but rebuilt the CAD. I also made the addition of my own fan duct. In the image below you will see I used a cable chain and a laser cut acrylic plate to mount it for wire management. This is an area of active work for myself.

comments.text: You'll want to aim for about 85c for the ambient temperature when you go for active heating. Any hotter, and you'll find heat creep, up your hot end is impossible to stop, and you'll hit jam city, but at that temperature, you're close enough to the TG of ABS, that inter-layer adhesion is literally as strong as adhesion on a perpendicular axis.
comments.author: Hawking

comments.text: Is the bed pretty stable with the Z wheels like that?  I like the idea of keeping the moving parts inside the cube
comments.author: spiffcow

comments.text: It has been very stable.  I have an auto bed leveling setup, so that takes care of any off canter of the bed.  The back bearing are preloaded with hand pressure only.  I did not put the ACME nuts for the z axis at the center of mass, I put them just behind so that the forces remained balanced and always put a constant moment on the bearings which is better than an unpredictable moment that would have been caused by mounting at the center of mass.  I cannot perceive any movement of the bed when torqued by hand but I am sure there would be some deflection if you measured it.  However, the bed always moves slowly and is fixed while printing a layer so as long as those forces are balanced the plate remains nice and flat in the original orientation when it was calibrated.  I figured you were trying to limit the X/Y play in the setup, which the V bearings helped with and any rotational motion would be dealt with by the fact that the acme nuts being biased off center of mass and a non moving platform.  I reserved the ability to put bearing in the front too, but they weren't needed.  Bottom Line - It has worked very well for me.
comments.author: spiffcow

comments.text:
I also really like the idea of running the V-wheels in the inside of the extrusions. I was going to try it myself, but it looked like someone on Openbuilds already tried it and they weren't happy with the the results. (PrintAir CoreXY by Keith Davis)
Couldn't quite see why it shouldn't work with adequate pre-loading.
comments.author: Hawking

comments.text: I think preload was important but also the placement of the Z-Axis screws.  I thought of it like this, the z screws handle the Z forces while the bearing have to take care of the X and Y.  All the bearing need to do is constrain the platform in the X and Y.  The trick to minimizing the amount of forces that have to be constrained in the X and Y axis was to reduce the moment created by the platform and this was done by placing the z axis screws near the center of gravity.  I choose to mount them slightly behind the center of gravity to proved a known direction of any moment while keeping it small.
comments.author: KDan

comments.text:
Thanks for the reply. I can certainly see that taking the load off of the Z-axis wheels by moving the Z screws forward (like D. Spauda did), is going to make a big difference.
I was thinking of doing the same thing on the Y axis. It looks like Keith Davis was planning do do this with his CoreXY enclosed, and followup PrintAir CoreXY designs. It looks like Keith was doing this because he wanted to go with a belt driven Z axis - an idea which I think has a lot of merit. Getting rid of leadscrews entirely eliminates the possibility of Z-wobble. The problem may be getting sufficient torque amplification to lift a heavy build plate. One stage of gear reduction via a single set of 2:1 ratio GT2 pulleys may not have been enough. You'd probably need at least 4:1 reduction in order to be able to lift the bed with a single motor.
In any case, your design is really a step forward. Thanks for sharing it,
comments.author: Hawking

comments.text: Is the bed pretty stable with the Z wheels like that?  I like the idea of keeping the moving parts inside the cube
comments.author: spiffcow

comments.text:
Very nice, how did you make the hood? What material is that?
Interesting Z setup at the back.
comments.author: cfeniak

comments.text:
Thanks,
Most of the panels, to include to top are made from 1/8in ABS sheet. The DXF is attached. The sides of the machine were made earlier and I used 1/8in white board material from the big box stores. This worked pretty well but it didn't turn out well for the hood, so I switched material. As for the platform, See above. It has worked great for me.

description.text:
Update 30th October 2017

I've added a revised version with the upper screw hole part removed on one side.

This is to allow a little more flexibility in the plastic around the screw clamp area.

This is a bracket I designed to allow a full size shelf to be fitted at any height underneath an Ikea table fitted with Adils 40mm legs.

The bracket clamps around the legs, just slide onto the leg and lock in place at the desired height using a 25mm (approx) 4mm bolt, tighten enough to stop the bracket sliding, if it won't twist on the leg using reasonable force, then it's tight enough.

There are two screw holes in the top of the bracket to attach to the shelf.

This small car has a Raspberry Pi2 B and SD Card with Raspbian Jessie, 4 DC motor on base frame, 2 Dual H Bridge motor driver, 16 channels PWM controller for the motor drivers and TPLINK wireless USB adapter. The software is written in C#. The mechanical design is very simple, only 3 parts. Pi and the PWM controller communicate on I2C. The Myo is associated with an Android device, which is connected to WIFI network. WIFI network via Raspberry reaches and passes the Myo instructions. A Raspberry process and manage the hardware.

print_settings.Notes:: A few of the smaller pieces may need a brim/raft. See below for specific printing suggestions (just suggestions as each user has personal preferences for small parts).

description.text:
A scene from the 'Pickles' comic strip.

If you are unfamiliar with the Pickles comic strip, by Brian Crane, I strongly suggest checking it out on the web. The characters are just that, they are 'characters' and my wife and I love the strip.

The husband's name is Earl and the wife's name is Opal.

The picture that I used for modeling is from the 25th anniversary of the strip and is included below.

The completed model after assembly is 128mm x 189mm x 203mm high and none of the parts require supports!

Enjoy!

Printer:

FlashForge Creator X

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

A few of the smaller pieces may need a brim/raft. See below for specific printing suggestions (just suggestions as each user has personal preferences for small parts).

I used the picture below as my model guide. With a lot of input from my wife, I translated the picture to a 3D design using Blender. A final render from Blender of my model prior to slicing for 3D printing is included below.

I use a rule for myself to create models with no angles greater than 60 degrees to ensure that supports will not be required. I also try to conform to the original picture as closely as possible while considering the 60 degree limit.

Even with my reasonable catalog of ABS colors, I had trouble matching the original colors. I bought two new colors but still took liberty with the colors overall.

Original artists Pickles 25th anniversary scene Render from Blender

Colors and multiple printed pieces

Following are the colors that I used and notes if pieces are to be printed multiple times. Consider this simply as a guide as to which pieces need to have the same color.
..
Skin/Beige:
earl_arm_right
earl_arm_left
opal_arm_right
opal_arm_left
opal_leg_right
opal_leg_left
opal_head
earl_head
..
White:
earl_hair_top
earl_hair_bottom
opal_hair
opal_shoe_left
opal_shoe_right
newspaper
earl_eyebrow_right
earl_eyebrow_left
earl_moustashe_top
earl_moustashe_bottom
earl_eyewhite_left
earl_eyewhite_right
opal_eyewhite_right
opal_eyewhite_left
..
Any color (hidden piece):
bump (8 copies)
..
Black:
eyeblack (four copies)
earl_glasses
opal_glasses
..
Brown:
chair_leg (four copies)
earl_shoe_right
earl_shoe_left
..
Grey:
earl_leg_right
earl_leg_left
..
Natural (off-white):
earl_shirt_bottom
earl_shirt_top
..
Purple:
opal_shirt_top
opal_shirt_bottom
..
Light Blue:
opal_skirt
..
Dark Blue:
earl_pants_top
earl_pants_bottom
..
Orange:
chair
chair_cushion
..
Light Brown/Gold:
rug

Printing and assembly tips

Printing tips:
-Take particular care with left and right pieces. Many of them look very similar but are not the same.
-When printing the eyeblacks I left the extra brim on instead of cleaning up the pieces. This resulted in a clean fit into the eyewhites and result in a solid eyeblack showing.
-For small pieces I personally print them at 50% infill and two shells. This ensures plenty of time for clean prints on my printer.

Assembly tips:
-The diagram below will help in assembling the model. A larger copy is included in the downloads section
-The model is meant to be glued together. Be careful when gluing to ensure that you do not 'glue yourself into a corner'. The hands/arms/legs need to be glued in at the same time that the connecting pieces are glued, so that you have room to position them.
-Both eyeglasses are placed on the faces with the bridge down, just over the nose. This might not be obvious from the diagram.

Assembly diagram (a larger copy is in the downloads section)

description.text: https://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/texas-instruments/TPA3111D1PWPR/296-25121-1-ND/2138599

Being a female with long hair which I usually wear pinned up leads to one major problem when traveling: the loss of bobby pins.  Altoids tins are the answer, for hair ties as well but that's another story. The problem I soon found was that my variety of bobby pins and hair clips got so messed up, with the little ones often falling to the bottom and difficult to retrieve from the corners of the tin.  I found several altoids tin dividers on thingiverse but they broke the tin into more numerous and smaller segments usually for pills.  These dividers keep the segments slightly larger. They fit securely and allow the lids to latch fully close but they may wiggle around a little bit.  So far they have kept things very organized and bobby pins remain unlost for three months on the road and counting.

description.text:
This is a model of a typical boxer engine like what you would find in a Volkswagen Beetle or Karmann Ghia.

Each piece can be printed without support.

Snap together and turn the crank.

If you found this useful, please share your work and be sure to peruse my other submissions which are almost as varied as they are many:

title: Upper Filament Guide New Matter MOD-t
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Replacement Filament Guide (Upper) for my New Matter MOD-t. The nuts that hold the guide in place broke off and I decided to build a replacement myself. Not sure if using a PLA replacement part with PLA filament will be OK or not, but since it's far from the hot-end, it should essentially be OK.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/ljxu98FltJJ

Printer:

NewMatter MOD-t

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.05

Infill:

100

Notes:

I have yet to test it over a longer period of time. It should do as a temporary replacement though until I get the proper replacement in ABS.

Since the piece is quite small, you might be better off by using Rafts when printing. It should help with the supports and the piece sticking in place. Also, I disabled the nozzle lift setting, which resulted in a much better (but still not perfect) finish of the small edge on the top.

I printed with a rather slow printing speed (20mm/s)

Finish

Depending on your Filament, print quality and more, you might have to use a sharp knive or sand paper to finish the part. Two things are crucial:

  • The filament must easily pass through the guide (pay attention to the small edge at the bottom)
  • The hinges might need some tuning to fit as nicely and snuggly into the holes of the extruder enclosure.
